title: Usefulness of interferon-γ release assay for the diagnosis of sputum smear-negative pulmonary and extra-pulmonary TB in Zhejiang Province, China
summary: This paper investigates the usefulness of interferon-γ release assay (IGRA) for diagnosing smear-negative pulmonary and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis. The study compares the diagnostic performance of IGRA with TB antibody tests in various patient groups, finding that IGRA has a higher sensitivity than TB antibody tests but similar specificity.
methodology: The study used a combination of clinical data collection, laboratory testing (TB-IGRA and TB-Ab), and statistical analysis to evaluate the diagnostic performance of IGRA in various patient groups.
statistics: Student's t-tests, Pearson chi-square and Fisher exact tests were used for statistical analysis
research_outcomes: The study found that IGRA has a higher sensitivity than TB antibody tests but similar specificity. The detection ratio of TB-IGRA was 89.4% (449 of 502), while the detection ratios of the TB group and extrapulmonary TB group were 90.0% (350 of 389) and 87.6% (99 of 113), respectively.

title: Ectopic Relapse of Anti-neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibody-associated Pituitary Vasculitis with No Elevation of Anti-neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies after Renal Remission
summary: This paper reports a case of vasculitis relapse in the pituitary gland with no ANCA elevation after renal remission. The authors describe the clinical presentation, diagnosis, and treatment of this rare condition, highlighting the importance of considering alternative diagnoses and treatments for patients with GPA-related pituitary involvement.
methodology: The study employed a case report methodology, presenting a detailed description of a single patient's clinical course and treatment.
research_outcomes: The authors successfully treated the patient with rituximab therapy, resulting in a decrease in pituitary gland volume and relief from symptoms.

title: Barriers and Facilitators of Screening for Sexually Transmitted Infections in Adolescent Girls and Young Women in Mombasa, Kenya: A Qualitative Study
summary: This qualitative study explores the barriers and facilitators of screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) among adolescent girls and young women in Mombasa, Kenya. The research found that participants were willing to participate in STI screening but faced several barriers, including lack of symptoms, fear of positive test results, parental notification, stigmatization from parents, family members, and the community. The study suggests that addressing these barriers is crucial for improving adolescent girls' participation in research and developing interventions targeted at this population.
methodology: qualitative study using in-depth interviews (IDIs) and focus group discussions (FGDs)
research_outcomes: adolescent girls and young women are willing to participate in STI screening but face several barriers, including lack of symptoms, fear of positive test results, parental notification, stigmatization from parents, family members, and the community.

title: The Evolving Concept of Cluster Headache: A Historical Perspective
summary: This paper provides a historical perspective on the understanding and treatment of cluster headache, tracing its evolution from ancient times to modern-day approaches. Despite significant advances in medical knowledge, the exact cause of cluster headache remains unknown, with various theories proposed over the centuries, including neuralgia and peripheral nerve involvement.
methodology: Historical analysis of case reports and medical literature
research_outcomes: The study highlights the changing understanding of cluster headache over time, from its initial description as a vascular headache to current theories involving neuralgia and peripheral nerve involvement.

title: Social Representations of Malaria in a Southern Malian Community: An Ethnographic Qualitative Study
summary: This ethnographic qualitative study examines the social representations of malaria in a southern Malian community. The research focuses on how local people's perceptions, knowledge, and practices regarding malaria affect therapeutic routes. Although machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this study, it contributes to understanding the complex dynamics of social representations and their impact on healthcare choices.
methodology: Ethnographic fieldwork with participant observations, informal conversations, semi-structured interviews, and bibliographical research
research_outcomes: The study found that local people's perceptions of malaria are shaped by cultural and popular representations, which can influence therapeutic choices. The integration of local knowledge with biomedical models is crucial for improving the National Malaria Control Programmes in Mali.

title: Multidrug Resistant and Extensively Drug Resistant Bacteria: A Study
summary: This study investigates the incidence of multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extensively drug-resistant (XDR) bacterial isolates in a tertiary care hospital. The research focuses on detecting MDR, XDR, and pandrug-resistant (PDR) bacteria, which poses a major threat to patient treatment due to increased morbidity and mortality, prolonged hospital stay, and economic loss.
methodology: The study used conventional methods for bacterial identification and antibiotic susceptibility testing. The Kirby Bauer disc diffusion method was employed as per Clinical Laboratory Standard Institute (CLSI) guidelines.
research_outcomes: The study found that 393 (37.1%) bacterial strains were MDR, 146 (13.8%) strains were XDR, and no PDR was isolated. The commonest MDR strains were detected from E. coli, followed by Klebsiella pneumoniae.
sources_of_inspiration: WHO declaration 'combat drug resistance: no action today, no cure tomorrow.'
European Centre for Disease Control (ECDC) and Centre for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC) definitions of MDR, XDR, and PDR bacteria

title: DUOX2 Variants are a Frequent Cause of Congenital Primary Hypothyroidism in Thai Patients
summary: This study investigates the genetic causes of congenital primary hypothyroidism (CH) in Thai patients. The researchers found that DUOX2 variants are a frequent cause of CH, with 25 out of 118 patients carrying either compound heterozygous or homozygous variants. The most common pathogenic DUOX2 variant was c.1588A>T, which is relatively common in the Thai population.
methodology: The study used clinical exome sequencing by next-generation sequencing to identify genetic variants associated with CH. The researchers developed an in-house gene list that covered 62 potential candidate genes related to CH and thyroid disorders.
statistics: Mann-Whitney U test was used for comparison between two groups of non-normally distributed data.
research_outcomes: The study found that DUOX2 variants are a frequent cause of CH in Thai patients, with 25 out of 118 patients carrying either compound heterozygous or homozygous variants. The most common pathogenic DUOX2 variant was c.1588A>T.

title: The association of blood urea nitrogen levels upon emergency admission with mortality in acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
summary: This study investigates the relationship between blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels and mortality in patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD). The results show that increased BUN levels are associated with hospital mortality, suggesting that BUN can be used as a prognostic indicator for AECOPD.
methodology: Retrospective observational cohort study
statistics: Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis, logistic regression models, propensity score matching
research_outcomes: Increased BUN levels are associated with hospital mortality in patients with AECOPD.

title: The role of epithelial-mesenchymal transition in the post-lung transplantation bronchiolitis obliterans
summary: This paper investigates the role of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in post-lung transplantation bronchiolitis obliterans. The study found that EMT is involved in the process of airway remodeling in BO, providing a potential target for future treatment.
methodology: The study used an allogeneic rat left lung orthotopic transplantation model to explore the histological structure changes in BO and detected the expression levels of EMT markers.
statistics: Fisher’s Exact test, Spearman’s rank correlation
research_outcomes: The study found that EMT is involved in the process of airway remodeling in BO, with a negative correlation between the expression levels of E-cadherin and Vimentin.

title: Providing quality end-of-life care to older people in the era of COVID-19: perspectives from five countries
summary: This paper explores the challenges of providing quality end-of-life care to older people during the COVID-19 pandemic. The authors discuss the importance of palliative and hospice care philosophy in alleviating distressing pain and other burdensome symptoms, and ensuring high-quality medico-ethical decision-making based on wishes and preferences.
methodology: The paper uses a qualitative approach, exploring the perspectives of clinicians and researchers from five countries on providing quality end-of-life care to older people during the COVID-19 pandemic.
research_outcomes: The authors highlight the importance of prioritizing palliative care for older vulnerable patients, and using clinical frailty scales to guide decision-making regarding hospitalization. They also emphasize the need for clinicians to act in the best interests of their patients in a transparent manner.

title: Outbreak of Vancomycin Resistant Enterococcus faecium (VREfm) in a Hematology Unit Identified Through Whole Genome Sequencing
summary: This paper describes an outbreak of Vancomycin Resistant Enterococcus faecium (VREfm) in a hematology unit using Whole Genome Sequencing. The study identifies a cluster of infections with high genetic similarity, suggesting an environmental niche in the hospital unit.
methodology: Whole Genome Sequencing and phylogenomic tree analysis
research_outcomes: The study identified 7 clusters of VREfm infections, with one cluster showing high genetic similarity and a prolonged period of infection.

title: Survey of Chiropractic Clinicians on Self-Reported Knowledge and Recognition of Concussion Injuries
summary: This paper surveys chiropractic clinicians' self-reported knowledge and recognition of concussion injuries, finding an overconfidence in MTBI diagnosis despite low knowledge scores. The study highlights the need for further education on MTBI recognition among chiropractors.
methodology: The study used a standardized survey instrument distributed to a captive audience of chiropractic practitioners at the Texas Chiropractic College annual symposium.
research_outcomes: The survey found that chiropractic clinicians have low knowledge scores and overconfidence in MTBI diagnosis, with only 27% average MTBI knowledge and recognition score. The primary action of suspected MTBI was to refer to a neurological specialist (76%).

title: Transient binocular blindness: A rare presentation of aortic dissection
summary: This paper presents a case study of a patient with aortic dissection who experienced transient binocular blindness. The authors highlight the importance of prompt detection and diagnosis of this life-threatening condition, which can present atypically. Despite its rarity, bedside carotid ultrasonography proved to be a helpful tool in assisting the diagnosis.
methodology: The study employed a case presentation approach, where the authors described a patient's symptoms and diagnostic findings. Bedside carotid ultrasonography was used as an initial screening tool for unstable patients.
research_outcomes: Prompt detection of atypical presenting aortic dissection can be life-saving. Extensive AD can present with bilateral blindness, and bedside carotid ultrasonography is a helpful tool in assisting diagnosis.

title: Cardio-pathogenic variants in unexplained intrauterine fetal death: a retrospective pilot study
summary: This paper investigates the prevalence and spectrum of cardio-pathogenic variants in fetuses with unexplained intrauterine fetal death. The study found that 87.5% of fetuses carried 33 variants in 22 different cardio-specific genes, but no significant clinical differences were evident between fetuses with and without these variants.
methodology: The study used a retrospective pilot design, reviewing cases of intrauterine fetal death delivered at two tertiary university hospitals. DNA from post-mortem fibroblastic tissue samples was retrieved for clinical exome sequencing.
research_outcomes: The study found that cardio-pathogenic variants may contribute to unexplained intrauterine fetal death, but further research is needed to confirm this association.

title: Prevalence of Intestinal Parasite Infections and Their Associated Factors among Food Handlers Working in Selected Catering Establishments from Bule Hora, Ethiopia
summary: This study investigates the prevalence of intestinal parasitic infections among food handlers in selected catering establishments in Bule Hora Town, Ethiopia. The research found a high prevalence rate of 46.3% and identified factors such as poor personal hygiene, inadequate sanitary facilities, and improper handling and storage of food and utensils as contributing to the spread of disease.
methodology: A descriptive cross-sectional study was conducted between March and April 2020 using a systematic sampling technique. Data analysis was done using SPSS version 20.
research_outcomes: The study found that the prevalence of intestinal parasites in this study was high and contributed by low socioeconomic status and poor environmental and personal hygiene.

title: Impairment of insulin-stimulated Akt/GLUT4 signaling is associated with cardiac contractile dysfunction and aggravates I/R injury in STZ-diabetic Rats
summary: This study investigates the mechanisms of diabetes that cause cardiac dysfunctions in STZ-diabetic rats with and without myocardial I/R injuries. The research focuses on the role of insulin signaling, specifically Akt/GLUT4 signaling molecules, in cardiac contractile dysfunction and its aggravation of I/R injury.
methodology: The study used a combination of molecular and organism-level approaches to investigate the effects of diabetes on cardiac function. The researchers induced diabetes in rats using streptozotocin (STZ) and then subjected them to myocardial ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury.
research_outcomes: The study found that impairment of insulin-stimulated Akt/GLUT4 signaling is associated with cardiac contractile dysfunction and aggravates I/R injury in STZ-diabetic rats. The results indicate that cardiac contractile dysfunction caused by a defect in insulin-stimulated Akt/GLUT4 may be a major reason for the high mortality rate in I/R injured diabetic rats.

title: T-Cell Lymphoblastic Lymphoma Arising in the Setting of Myeloid/Lymphoid Neoplasms with Eosinophilia
summary: This paper investigates T-lymphoblastic lymphoma (T-LBL) occurring in the setting of myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with eosinophilia. The study evaluates the clinical, morphological, immunohistochemical and molecular features of 11 cases and suggests that LMO2 immunostaining may be a useful marker to identify T-LBL developing in this context.
methodology: Retrospective evaluation of clinical, morphological, immunohistochemical and molecular features of 11 cases of T-LBL occurring in the setting of myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with eosinophilia
research_outcomes: The study found that LMO2 immunostaining was negative in 9/11 cases, and suggests its potential use as a diagnostic marker for T-LBL occurring in this context.

title: Awareness of Therapeutic Benefits of Green Tea among Dental Fraternity
summary: This paper explores the awareness and knowledge of green tea's therapeutic benefits among dental students. The study uses a questionnaire-based survey to assess participants' understanding of green tea's effects on oral health, including its anti-inflammatory properties, ability to reduce bad breath, and potential to cure dental caries, gingivitis, periodontitis, and oral malignancy.
methodology: The study used a descriptive survey design with a questionnaire-based approach. The participants were undergraduate students of various dental colleges who completed the survey online through Google Forms.
research_outcomes: The results showed that most participants were aware of green tea's benefits, including its ability to reduce bad breath and cure dental caries, gingivitis, periodontitis, and oral malignancy. However, some participants were not aware of these effects.

title: HIV Infection: Time from Diagnosis to Initiation of Antiretroviral Therapy in Portugal, a Multicentric Study
summary: This study evaluates the time from HIV diagnosis to antiretroviral therapy (ART) initiation in Portugal, aiming to understand the factors influencing this process. The research focuses on the healthcare system's efficiency and patient associations' support in navigating PLWH through referral and linkage to care.
methodology: The study employed a twofold design: quantitative analysis of hospital records from five Portuguese hospitals and qualitative individual interviews with three representatives of patient associations.
research_outcomes: The study found that the average time from diagnosis to ART initiation was above the recommended 14 days, highlighting the need for improved healthcare system efficiency. Patient associations' support in navigating PLWH through referral and linkage to care is crucial.

title: A Scenario-Based Survey of Expert Echocardiography Recommendations for Patients With Staphylococcus aureus Bacteremia at Varying Risk for Endocarditis
summary: This paper presents a scenario-based survey of expert echocardiography recommendations for patients with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia at varying risk for endocarditis. The study found that experts demonstrate active and precise risk stratification when recommending echocardiography strategies, but disagreement exists as to the appropriate investigation of lower-risk cases.
methodology: The study used a survey approach with 656 respondents from 24 countries, presenting various scenarios for Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and asking experts to recommend echocardiography strategies.
research_outcomes: Experts demonstrated active and precise risk stratification when recommending echocardiography strategies, but disagreement exists as to the appropriate investigation of lower-risk cases.

title: Free-living gait characteristics in ageing and Parkinson’s disease: impact of environment and ambulatory bout length
summary: This study investigates the impact of environment and ambulatory bout length on gait characteristics in people with Parkinson’s disease (PD) and age-matched controls. The researchers used accelerometer-based body worn monitors to collect data in both laboratory and free-living environments, exploring differences between groups and the influence of bout length on gait characteristics.
methodology: Quantitative gait analysis using a theoretical model of gait to inform selection of gait characteristics
research_outcomes: The study found that free-living data showed differences between groups in gait characteristics, with longer ambulatory bouts highlighting significant differences for pace, rhythm, and asymmetry.

title: Coronavirus Pandemic Roles and challenges of coordinated public health laboratory response against COVID-19 pandemic in Africa
summary: This paper discusses the roles and challenges of coordinated public health laboratory responses to the COVID-19 pandemic in Africa. It highlights the need for concerted efforts from multiple sectors targeting humans, animals, and the environment, and proposes the adoption of the 'One Health' strategy as an ideal public health intervention.
methodology: The paper uses a literature review approach to discuss the challenges and roles of laboratory responses in Africa. It also discusses the use of molecular tests as the gold standard for COVID-19 diagnosis, and proposes alternative protocols that could augment RT-PCR.
research_outcomes: The study highlights the need for coordinated public health laboratory responses to the COVID-19 pandemic in Africa, and proposes the adoption of the 'One Health' strategy as an ideal public health intervention. It also discusses the challenges and limitations of serological assays and molecular tests.

title: Association of Low Levels of Vitamin D with Chronic Stable Angina: A Prospective Case-Control Study
summary: This study investigates the association between low levels of vitamin D and chronic stable angina in a prospective case-control study. The results show a correlation between vitamin D deficiency and chronic stable angina, suggesting that low levels of vitamin D may be an independent, potentially modifiable cardiovascular risk factor.
methodology: The study was a 2-year hospital-based prospective case-control study conducted in Sher-i-Kashmir Institute of Medical Sciences (SKIMS), Srinagar, Kashmir, India. One hundred patients with angiographically documented chronic stable angina and 100 matched controls were taken for the study.
statistics: chi-square test, Student's t-test, likelihood ratio, Levene's test for equality, analysis of variance (ANOVA), Mann-Whitney U test, and Fisher's exact test
research_outcomes: The results show a correlation between vitamin D deficiency and chronic stable angina. Low levels of vitamin D may be an independent, potentially modifiable cardiovascular risk factor.

title: Treating breast cancer metastasis with cabazitaxel-loaded polymeric micelles
summary: This paper explores the use of cabazitaxel-loaded polymeric micelles (PCMs) to treat breast cancer metastasis. The PCMs are shown to effectively inhibit tumor growth and lung metastases, with a 71.6% inhibition of tumor growth and a 93.5% reduction of lung metastases.
methodology: The study used in vitro characterization of PCMs, cellular uptake in metastatic 4T1 breast cancer cells, and in vivo evaluations to assess the anti-metastatic efficacy of PCMs.
research_outcomes: The results verify the anti-metastatic efficacy of PCMs, providing an encouraging strategy for treating breast cancer metastasis.

title: Efficacy of a Secondary Trifocal Sulcus IOL in Providing Near and Intermediate Vision in Patients with Prior Myopic Laser Vision Correction and Cataract Surgery
summary: This study evaluates the efficacy of a secondary trifocal sulcus intraocular lens (IOL) in providing near and intermediate vision to patients with prior myopic laser vision correction and cataract surgery. The IOL is designed to address the challenges presented by eyes with previous refractive surgery, offering improved visual outcomes compared to primary monofocal IOLs.
methodology: Prospective, single-arm, non-interventional unmasked study
research_outcomes: The trifocal sulcus IOL provided excellent distance and near vision, with a good range of functional vision. Uncorrected near VA was 0.2 logMAR or better in 80% of eyes (20/25). Binocular uncorrected distance visual acuity was 0.1 logMAR or better in all subjects.
